crossReferenceMarkers: past and past participle of bend

definitions: sharply curved or having an angle

examples.text: a piece of bent wire
his bent shoulders
a missionary bent on saving souls
a mob bent on violence
a bent cop
a man of religious bent
she had no natural bent for literature

etymologies: Middle English: from Old English beonet (recorded in place names), of West Germanic origin; related to German Binse

definitions: a stiff grass which is used for lawns and is a component of pasture and hay grasses.

notes.text: Agrostis and other genera, family Graminae: several species, including common bent (A. capillaris or 'tenuis')

definitions: the stiff flowering stalk of a grass

examples.text: those nasty bents of ryegrass that are very efficient at ducking the mower

definitions: any stiff-stemmed or rushlike grass or sedge.
shortDefinitions: stiff or rushlike grass or sedge

etymologies: Old English bendan ‘put in bonds, tension a bow by means of a string’, of Germanic origin; related to band

definitions: shape or force (something straight) into a curve or angle

examples.text: the rising wind bent the long grass

definitions: (of something straight) be shaped or forced into a curve or angle

examples.text: the oar bent as Lance heaved angrily at it

definitions: (of a road, river, or path) deviate from a straight line in a specified direction; have a sharply curved course

examples.text: the road bent left and then right
the river slowly bends around Davenport

notes.text: no object, usually with adverbial of direction

definitions: (of a person) incline the body downward from the vertical

examples.text: I bent over my plate
he bent down and picked her up
he bent to tie his shoelaces

definitions: move (a jointed part of the body) to an angled position

examples.text: extend your left leg and bend your right
Irene bent her head over her work

shortDefinitions: move body part to angled position

definitions: force or be forced to submit

examples.text: they want to bend me to their will
a refusal to bend to mob rule

shortDefinitions: force or be forced to submit

definitions: interpret or modify (a rule) to suit oneself or somebody else

examples.text: we cannot bend the rules, even for Darren

definitions: direct or devote (one's attention or energies) to a task

examples.text: Eric bent all his efforts to persuading them to donate some blankets
she bent once more to the task of diverting the wedding guests

definitions: attach (a sail or rope) by means of a knot

examples.text: sailors were bending sails to the spars

shortDefinitions: attach sail or cable with knot

etymologies: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French bande, Old French bende ‘flat strip’
